results:
The search results provide valuable information about the relationship between Sienkiewicz and romanticism/positivism, as well as comparisons between Mickiewicz and Słowacki in Polish literary tradition. Here's what I found:

## Sienkiewicz and Positivism vs. Romanticism

Henryk Sienkiewicz belongs to the positivist movement alongside Bolesław Prus ("Lalka", "Faraon"), Eliza Orzeszkowa ("Nad Niemnem", "Gloria victis"), and Maria Konopnicka (novels, patriotic poetry). In positivism, prose came to the forefront, especially novels and novellas, as these genres were better suited for realistic portrayal of reality, presenting social life and problems of ordinary people - Prus, Orzeszkowa, Sienkiewicz created primarily novels and novellas.

## Key Differences Between Romanticism and Positivism

Romanticism was based on the philosophy of emotion, soul and faith. Romantics believed in the power of intuition, in the spiritual and supernatural world. As Mickiewicz said: "measure your strength against your intentions" - believe in your possibilities, even if they seem unattainable.

Positivists looked at the world through a completely different prism. For them, facts, experience and empirical knowledge mattered. Positivism was based on scientism (cult of science) and utilitarianism (principle of utility). Representatives of this movement believed that only what can be measured, weighed and touched has real value.

In short - a romantic looked at the world with his heart, a positivist - with his mind.

## Mickiewicz and Słowacki Comparison

The most famous poets of the romantic era are often called Adam Mickiewicz and Juliusz Słowacki, classified among Polish romantic bards. The historical situation of this period and the tragic events associated with it had a great influence on each of them.

Mickiewicz, Słowacki, Krasiński - they all created primarily poetry, which best expressed feelings, states of mind, metaphysical experiences.

Juliusz Słowacki belongs to the second generation of romantics, debuting much later than Mickiewicz, essentially only during the November Uprising. He joins the emigrant community, however here his temporary recognition, which he could enjoy in Warsaw, disappears in the shadow of the master, Mickiewicz, the unquestioned first national bard.

## Literary Tradition and Impact

These poets shaped Polish national consciousness and set directions for literature development throughout the 19th century. The masterpieces of Mickiewicz, Słowacki, Prus and Sienkiewicz are still read, analyzed and adapted for contemporary culture. Their themes, motifs and characters have permanently entered our cultural imagination.

The search results show that Sienkiewicz, as a positivist writer, represented a fundamentally different literary approach compared to the romantic tradition established by Mickiewicz and Słowacki, focusing on rational, empirical approaches to literature rather than the emotional, spiritual emphasis of romanticism.
